item.title: Linear Models for Clasification - Fisher’s Linear Discriminant
item.description: 4.1.4 Fisher’s Linear Discriminant Linear classification model can be viewed as projecting the $D$-dimensional data onto a one-dimensional space. The equation $y=W^TX$ projects the $D$-dimensional input vector on a one dimensional space. Projection onto one dimension leads to a considerable loss of information and classes that are well-separated in the $D$-dimensional space may become overlapping in the one dimensional space. The goal of the classification problem is to adjust the weight $W$ so that we can have the projection that maximizes the separation.
